posts.content:
I wasn’t sure of starting a blog at first. I am a back-end developer. Any work I have done on CSS, JS or HTML was in college days. I thought it would be easy if I can publish blogs writing markdown files.
Few things that I was concerned about:
  Capital — I wanted the investment to be minimum. Didn’t wanted to manage a server or traffic on the site. I found Github pages to be a simple solution for someone starting a blog. As I already use GitHub for my projects, pushing blog changes would as simple as pushing my code.
  Time — I wanted the content to be more about writing rather than managing the post. I thought writing a post in markdown would be simple as most of the time I am on an editor/terminal. I can write, commit & push for publishing a new post.
  Content Management — I just wanted the support of markdown and the tool to be simple. I found Hugo and Jekyll. Both are static site generators. Both of them provide support for writing in markdown. Jekyll is already used by Github pages. But I went with Hugo. I found Hugo much faster than Jekyll plus it’s written in golang (what’s not to love).
  Hugo is fast, simple & performant. For starting a blog, I thought it would be best. I started by installing Hugo. I followed the quickstart guide on the Hugo blog. Finalized ‘pure’ theme. I wrote this article to test the rendering of the blog.
In the coming weeks, I am thinking of forking out the current theme repo and adjust it to my requirements. I will try to write another detailed post on each step involved in creating this blog.
